payload.humanPrompt:
Design a platform for users to submit batch workloads that may run distributed across many nodes (e.g., MPI/Ray/Julia distributed). Users can upload inputs, track progress, stream logs, retry failed steps, and enforce quotas per tenant.
Focus areas: scheduling model, job execution, data staging, retries/idempotency, multi-node coordination, isolation, cost controls.

payload.rationale: Delivery_realist brings a pragmatic perspective that emphasizes convergence and fairness, making them well-suited to mediate discussion and ensure balanced consideration of the proposal for this session.

As the Scalability Member, I am deeply familiar with the council’s goals around long-term system resilience and growth, so I can guide the discussion to balance differing perspectives while ensuring convergence on fair, scalable decisions.

payload.objective: Define high-level architecture, principal risks, and decision boundaries. Produce measurable acceptance criteria that implementation must satisfy.
Define high-level architecture, principal risks, and decision boundaries. Produce measurable acceptance criteria that implementation must satisfy.

payload.message: Propose a control-plane layered into: tenant API+auth, scheduler, execution controller, and storage/router. Scheduler batches work by priority/quota, maps to node pools (CPU/GPU/Network) and publishes placements to execution agents; those agents pull inputs from secured staging buckets, hook into MPI/Ray/Julia runtimes, stream logs via a central log relay, and report status to tracking service. Boundaries: per-tenant quotas enforced in scheduler, isolation via namespace+network policies in node pools, retries handled by controller using idempotent checkpoints and exponential backoff; multi-node coordination relies on runtime’s lock-step phases, with a heartbeat to controller to detect stragglers. Principal risks: quota exhaustion/over-commit, data transfer bottlenecks, runaway retries, inconsistent states when nodes fail. Acceptance: (1) All jobs report progress/log streams with <=5s latency from agent events. (2) Scheduler must refuse job submissions when tenant quota >=90% usage and signal. (3) Failed steps retried up to N with idempotent checkpoints; no duplicate outputs. (4) Data staging throughput meets 70% of cluster network capacity without exceeding tenant storage quota. (5) Multi-node jobs recover or fail within one expected job-duration window on node loss, triggering alerts.

Layer core services into: (1) Tenant-facing API handling auth, catalog, quota accounting, and submission portals; (2) Policy-driven scheduler projecting quotas, resource availability, and priority, producing placements for node pools; (3) Execution controller (state machine + heartbeat) orchestrating runtime adapters that bootstrap MPI/Ray/Julia clusters, coordinate staging, retries, and log capture; (4) Data/telemetry mesh: multi-tenant staging buckets, log relay, progress store, and telemetry bus feeding dashboards/alerts.
Risk focus: scheduler being single-point bottleneck, data-transfer spikes, retry storms, and multi-node orchestration blind spots. Boundaries: scheduler owns quota + placement decisions; execution controller owns retries/idempotency and runtime adaptation; tenant storage and compute isolation enforced via namespaces + cgroups + network policies. Acceptance criteria: (a) Scheduler decisions applied within 2s of submission and enforces <90% quota before acceptance; (b) Execution controller detects per-node heartbeat loss within 10s and triggers retry/failure policies; (c) Log/progress events delivered to tenants within 5s via streaming relay; (d) Data staging throughput per tenant stays under their quota and overall staging service stays within 70% of NIC capacity; (e) Multi-node jobs resume/notify within expected job duration window on node failures with no duplicate artifacts per retry policy.

Advocate for layered control plane: tenant API/quotas, scheduler, execution controller, data/telemetry layer. Scheduler keeps placement decisions fast (<=2s) and refuses new jobs when tenant usage ≥90%; execution controller stitches together runtime bootstrapping, retries with checkpoints, and heartbeat monitoring (detect node loss <10s). Data staging uses per-tenant buckets tied to quotas, pushing via relay that keeps log/progress latency ≤5s. Boundaries: scheduler owns quota/placement policies, controller owns retries/idempotency, runtimes own multi-node coordination, and storage service enforces tenant isolation via namespaces+network policies. Acceptance: (1) Scheduler enforces quotas before acceptance and publishes placements ≤2s; (2) Heartbeat loss triggers retry/fail within next expected job-duration window; (3) Log/progress streams delivered ≤5s; (4) Data staging throughput hits ≥70% NIC without exceeding tenant quota; (5) Retries produce no duplicate outputs/checkpointed steps.

payload.objective: Define high-level architecture, principal risks, and decision boundaries. Produce measurable acceptance criteria that implementation must satisfy.

payload.message: Suggest we elevate the decision boundaries: (1) Scheduler must be horizontally scalable, employing optimistic queuing per tenant so that quota enforcement and cost controls happen before job admission; fallback policy is explicit rejection when ≥90% quota or cost threshold reached. (2) Execution controller retains sole mutation authority over job state, coordinating retries/idempotency via checkpoint tokens and ensuring distributed runtimes report heartbeats (loss detected <10s). (3) Data staging mesh enforces isolation via per-tenant namespace + signed URLs, with transfer throttles tied to quota usage; streaming logs/progress stay within 5s of agent emission. Key risks: quota over-commit, retry storms, cross-tenant data leakage, unexpected multi-node churn. Acceptance criteria: (a) Scheduler responds with placement or quota rejection within 2s; (b) Controller reacts to heartbeat loss in ≤10s and either retries or fails job within one expected job-duration window; (c) Logs/progress delivered ≤5s; (d) Data-stage throughput per tenant capped by quota and sustains ≥70% cluster NIC without oversubscription; (e) Retries rely on checkpoints so no duplicate artifacts are emitted.

Aligning on services: API+auth/quotas, scheduler, execution controller, and staging/telemetry mesh. Emphasize scheduler horizontal scalability using optimistic tenant queues so quota/cost checks always precede placement; reject above 90% usage. Execution controller holds job-state mutations, orchestrates runtime adapters, retries via checkpoint tokens, and reacts to heartbeats (<10s) to keep multi-node coordination observable. Staging mesh enforces per-tenant namespaces, signed URLs, and throttles transfer to quota. Key risks: scheduler bottleneck, retry storms from cascading failures, data leakage, and runtime churn. Acceptance: (1) Scheduler replies within 2s with placement/rejection; (2) Controller detects heartbeat loss ≤10s and retries/fails within expected duration; (3) Logs/progress delivered ≤5s; (4) Tenant staging throughput capped by quota yet sustains ≥70% NIC without oversubscription; (5) Retries driven by checkpoints so duplicates prevented.

Layering seems agreed: API/auth+quota, scheduler, execution controller, staging/telemetry mesh. I’d emphasize decision boundaries and rollout: (1) Scheduler must be stateless, horizontally scalable, and can only accept jobs when tenant usage+projected cost ≤90%; leases used for placement (<2s). (2) Execution controller is sole mutator of job state and coordinates runtime adapters; retries follow checkpoint tokens with exponential backoff and an overall cap, guaranteeing no duplicate outputs. (d) Staging throughput per tenant capped by quota yet utilizes ≥70% NIC overall without oversubscription. Scheduler enforces per-tenant quotas/cost thresholds before admission, controller is sole mutator of job state/retries via checkpoint tokens, runtimes handle multi-node coordination but surface heartbeats, and staging enforces isolation/throughput throttles. Principal risks: quota over-commit, scheduler bottleneck, retry storms, cross-tenant data leakage, node churn. Key decision boundaries: scheduler owns placement/quota/cost gating, controller owns retries/idempotency, staging owns isolation, runtimes own distributed execution semantics. (4) Tenant staging throughput capped by quota, averaging ≥70% NIC but never oversubscribed. (5) Retries use checkpoints so idempotency is provable and outputs never duplicated.

payload.objective: Critique unresolved ambiguities from the high-level pass and resolve them. Produce concrete implementation specifics: APIs, state/resources, scheduler behavior, lease/coordination mechanics, failure modes, and staged rollout tasks.

payload.message: Implementation specifics: expose REST/GRPC API (POST /v1/jobs {tenantId, spec, inputsRef, priority}; GET /v1/jobs/{id}; POST /v1/jobs/{id}/retry; GET /v1/jobs/{id}/logs?tail=1m) plus WebSocket/events for progress+logs. Auth ties to tenant quotas stored in quota service (compute, storage, ingress/egress). Scheduler is stateless, backed by optimistic per-tenant queues (priority+cost). Admission occurs when cached quota usage+projected cost <90%; else reject with reason. Scheduler allocates node leases (resource bundle + lease TTL 30s) via etcd/consul, writes placement to job state, publishes to execution controller stream. Execution controller owns job state, retries limited (default 3) with checkpoint tokens (MD5 of step outputs) stored in durable meta store; uses exponential backoff and enforces idempotency before marking complete. Agents pull placements, stage inputs via signed URLs from per-tenant namespaces with throttle guard (token bucket) tied to storage quota, attach to runtimes, stream logs through log relay to telemetry bus with <=5s latency, and send heartbeat every 5s; controller flags missing heartbeat >10s and either retries or fails within expected duration. Multi-node jobs coordinate via runtime (MPI/Ray/Julia) but controller uses lease negotiation to ensure consistent node lists; any node loss triggers runtime restart if checkpoint available or fails job. Failure modes: quota cache staleness, node pool exhaustion, staging panic, retry storms; monitor metrics and circuit-break. Rollout: phase1 - API+scheduler+quota service with single node pool; phase2 - execution controller with agent integration+staging; phase3 - telemetry/logs+retry policies; phase4 - scale to multi-node runtimes + alerts. Require CI that simulates quota breaches, heartbeat failures, and retry dedupe to validate acceptance criteria.

payload.message:
To settle remaining execution uncertainties, let’s codify defaults and rollout: 
1. API/State: REST+gRPC for POST /v1/jobs (tenantId, spec, estimatedCores, expectedRuntime, inputRefs, priority), GET/DELETE/POST retry, WebSocket/event-stream per tenant for progress/log updates. Job state stored in strongly consistent store (e.g., Spanner/Cockroach) with schema {jobId, tenantId, status, placementLeaseId, checkpoints[], costEstimate}. Retry API increments retryBudget if <default(3) and resets placement. 
2. Scheduler: stateless. Per-tenant optimistic queue (priority+cost) fed by API. Quota/cost cache (TTL=5s) reads compute/storage/egress usage; rejects if current+estimate ≥90% or monthly budget breached. Allocates lease via etcd (TTL=30s) describing node pool, resource vector, expected runtime, writes placement record, publishes to controller topic. If node pool lacks capacity, scheduler throttles, responds with ETA from /v1/nodepools capacity view and enqueues job with backoff (base 5s). Lease renewal requires heartbeat from controller; expiration triggers requeue. 
3. Execution Controller: sole mutator. State machine: PENDING→STAGING→RUNNING→COMPLETED/FAILED. Coordinates runtime adapters (MPI/Ray/Julia) via runtime client, stage via signed URLs from per-tenant namespace (throttled by token bucket tied to storage quota). Heartbeat every 5s; mark lost after 2 misses (<10s). Retries limited default 3, exponential backoff, checkpoint tokens (digest+uri) stored in meta store; before success verify digest matches to prevent duplicates. On heartbeat loss, controller either retries using checkpoint or fails job with alert if retry budget exhausted. 
4. Data staging/logs: Agents fetch signed URLs, throttle to quota, stage inputs to local cache, stream logs/progress via gRPC relay to telemetry bus (≤5s latency) and write to durable store for replay. 
5. Multi-node coordination: Runtime adapters register node list via controller lease. Node loss triggers runtime restart path if checkpoints exist; else controller fails and triggers retry. 
6. Failure models: quota cache divergence (compare periodic true usage), node pool exhaustion (auto-scale + backpressure), staging saturations (circuit-break, spill-to-disk), retry storms (retry budget + controller gating). 
7. Rollout phases: 
• Phase1 API+auth+quota store + stateless scheduler + single node pool, verifying quota rejection and placements. 
• Phase2 add execution controller, agents, data staging mesh, log relay; test heartbeats/retries. 
• Phase3 add telemetry dashboards, retry/idempotency validations (checkpoint digests) and high-throughput staging quotas. 
• Phase4 scale multi-node runtimes, auto-scaling node pools, alerts for heartbeat failures/over-quota and CI simulating quota breaches/node loss/duplicate prevention.

executionBrief.objective: Roll out the approved distributed batch platform plan across API, scheduler, controller, staging/log mesh, and verification suites.
executionBrief.recommendedExecutorProfile: Platform Delivery Lead with infra and ops experience.
steps: Phase1: release API/auth/quotas plus stateless scheduler and single node pool, validating placement and quota rejection flows.
Phase2: deploy execution controller, agents, staging/log mesh, verifying heartbeats, retries, signed URLs, and ≤5s telemetry latency.
Phase3: add telemetry dashboards, checkpoint idempotency checks, high-throughput staging quotas, and failure monitoring/alerts.
Phase4: scale multi-node runtimes, autoscale node pools, enable alerts, and run CI chaos tests for quota breaches, heartbeat loss, and node failures.
risks: Quota cache drift causing oversubscription or unnecessary rejections.
Controller/agent heartbeat loss leaving multi-node jobs hanging.
Data staging throttles or log relay saturation degrading workloads.
Retry storms producing duplicate outputs if checkpoints fail.
Node pool exhaustion delaying scheduling and frustrating tenants.
acceptanceCriteria: Scheduler responds within 2s with placement or rejection when tenant usage hits ≥90%.
Controller resolves heartbeat loss within 10s, retries/fails within job window, and prevents duplicate artifacts.
Telemetry/log progress delivered within 5s via the streaming relay.
Tenant staging throughput stays within quotas while using ≥70% NIC without oversubscription.
CI validates quota breaches, heartbeat loss, node failures, and checkpoint dedupe before full rollout.

payload.finalResolution: Plan adopted; proceed with phased rollout, implementation APIs, and verification suites.
